title: How many total passengers will Australian airline Qantas carry in the second half of 2020?
possible_answers: More than 20 million but less than 24 million
preds: Good news, but it still won't be enough for anything other than bin 1. https://in.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-australia/inching-toward-normal-australia-eases-some-covid-19-curbs-idUSL1N2I801E

— "South Australia officials say a worker at a pizza shop lied about the circumstances of his exposure to the coronavirus, leading the region to a strict lockdown earlier this week ... South Australia Premier Steven Marshall announced the six-day coronavirus lockdown on Monday to curtail a growing virus outbreak in the area. As a result, schools were closed and outdoor exercise and non-essential businesses were banned ... But those restrictions are ending three days early, after officials discovered the worker from the restaurant, Woodville Pizza Bar, lied about his exposure and interaction with others." https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/11/20/936957351/australian-state-cuts-covid-lockdown-short-saying-man-lied-to-contact-tracers — "Qantas chief executive Alan Joyce expects Australia's largest carrier to stop burning through cash and restore seat capacity to at least half its pre-virus levels by Christmas, a rare note of optimism from an airline industry devastated by the coronavirus pandemic ... Qantas has been hit hard by the virus, which prompted Australia to close its international borders to non-residents and restrict travel between states. In May the airline revealed it was burning A$40m ($29m) per week and that most international routes would remain closed until mid-2021." https://www.ft.com/content/2c224177-07d6-470a-a9ad-acb2d094059a Even both of these positive developments/notes still do not allow for the possibility of anything other than bin 1.

"The Australian state of South Australia is entering a mandatory lockdown lasting six days that began at midnight Thursday local time, with residents required to stay home to stop the spread of the virus ... Overall, South Australia has discovered a total of 36 cases statewide since Sunday, according to the BBC, making them the first known infections in the community in six months." https://www.npr.org/sections/coronavirus-live-updates/2020/11/18/936175398/south-australia-enters-circuit-breaker-coronavirus-lockdown?t=1605805827629

Not a chance of there being more than 16 mil passengers in the second half of 2020 — "Qantas Airways said on Friday that Australian state border closures due to the coronavirus pandemic had cost it A$100 million ($71 million) ... The airline is running less than 30% of its normal domestic capacity due to border closures, having earlier expected to be operating around 60% at this time ... Joyce said if Queensland opened its borders to the country’s most populous state, New South Wales, domestic capacity could reach up to 50% by Christmas ... Qantas has grounded almost all of its international flights." https://www.cnbc.com/2020/10/23/qantas-airways-takes-profit-hit-from-australias-state-border-closures.html

"Before Victoria's second wave, industry analysts were modelling a return to 60 per cent of the domestic market by the end of the year ... Today it is predicted at about 40 per cent" [1]. In the second half of 2019, Qantas carried 28,876,000 passengers — 18,895,000 were domestic and 9,981,000 were international [2]. International flights are unlikely to resume until July 2021 [3], so we can exclude the 9,981,000 mil figure from consideration. 40% of the remaining possible 18,895,000 is 7,558,000 — still less than half of 16 million. Note that even this is optimistic because the aforementioned result of industry modeling is a return of 40% of the domestic market by *the end of the year*. [1] https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-08-24/future-of-flying-in-australia-coronavirus-will-see-normal-prices/12583198
[2] https://investor.qantas.com/FormBuilder/_Resource/_module/doLLG5ufYkCyEPjF1tpgyw/file/2020HY/HY20-Interim-Financial-Report.pdf
[3] https://www.cnn.com/2020/08/19/business/qantas-international-flights/index.html

Financial report for the financial year July 2019- June 2020 was released 20 August[1]. For the first half of this year Qantas lost 50%+ of it's passengers compared to the previous year (approximately 12 million 2019-20 to 27 million 2018-19). Considering that air traffic was pretty normal the first 2+ months of the year the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic is closer to a 75% decline in passenger numbers. 
There is simply no way Qantas will have even close to 16 million passengers the second half of 2020. 1. https://investor.qantas.com/investors/?page=result-centre

"With Australia's international borders all but shut and no sign of this changing, the Sydney-based carrier [Qantas] reiterated it was not anticipating resuming international flights until July 2021 at the earliest - with the possible exception of flights to New Zealand." https://www.bbc.com/news/business-53831056

International travel highly unlikely to be back by then, even a NZ travel bubble.  Second largest city shut down and borders closed so a while before domestic travel is back, other than sparingly, by the end of the year.

Qantas has mothballed its International fleet in a three-year plan to restructure its business as 90% of business has evaporated due to the onset of Covid-19.
The airline does have a domestic division that was hoping to retain 40% of its business within closed frontiers (possibly including Covid-19 free New Zealand) that would have amounted to 4.4 million passenger flights over a six-month period, (2019 had 22million over 12-month period).
However, this has been thwarted by either a Coronavirus spike (1st Wave) or the onset of a second wave, especially in Melbourne , Victoria and the States have been closing their borders to interstate travellers placing further pressure on the travel industry. 
https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/jun/28/real-vulnerability-qantas-job-cuts-show-covid-19-will-change-the-future-of-work  https://www.theguardian.com/business/2020/jun/25/qantas-to-cut-6000-jobs-and-keep-15000-stood-down-in-bid-to-survive-coronavirus-downturn  https://news.sky.com/story/coronavirus-qantas-cuts-thousands-of-jobs-as-it-plans-for-a-three-year-downturn-12014347  https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-53549861  https://uk.finance.yahoo.com/news/coronavirus-qantas-cuts-thousands-jobs-plans-three-downturn-022500042.html?guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly93d3cuZ29vZ2xlLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAAKNf2Rpw7NRChkCdmNjC3b1tacruTdcdU3zVNviu88heltvj0YLSTKGZvPQLr_9Sz0A12agkCO93dpK_6D87BkgrYMIgHJ0YvKSCOWxswvpZWlrPs8-A07oSzxldCEaHn5yU0kngVdaNahZ56-uGlcI579mdYX_2M5wxnz4f2lP-&_guc_consent_skip=1596798043  https://www.cnbc.com/2020/07/14/coronavirus-qantas-to-cut-nearly-all-international-flights-till-march-2021.html  https://simpleflying.com/qanatas-mojave-airline-graveyard/  https://news.rthk.hk/rthk/en/component/k2/1534026-20200625.htm

"Australia reported a record 15 deaths from COVID-19 on Wednesday, all in Victoria state, which was preparing to close much of its economy to control a second wave of infection that threatens to spread across the country ... The second-most populous state in Australia reported a record rise of 725 new COVID-19 cases despite having reimposed a lockdown on Melbourne, the state capital with a population of 5 million people, four weeks ago ... In northeastern Queensland state, Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk said travelers from New South Wales and the capital Canberra would be barred from Saturday. The state is already closed to Victorians." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-australia/australia-suffers-record-coronavirus-deaths-triggering-tighter-curbs-idUSKCN251053

May was down over 90% year-on-year [1] for domestic values and an even higher drop (+98%) for international [2]. While there has been a recent increase in cases [3,4], these seem to be contained with local lockdown measures, and from Vox [4], "the “highs” Australia is seeing right now are basically what some of America’s more well-off states are seeing on a good day." This means, though, there will be continued vigilance and a continued low travel numbers. Using the May data above [1,2], I projected forward with a 10% growth rate on my estimates from previous forecasts of monthly numbers [5,6], which gives a crazy low number of 1.3 million for July through December. I am going all in on the lowest bin.  [1] https://www.bitre.gov.au/statistics/aviation/domestic
[2] https://www.bitre.gov.au/statistics/aviation/international
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-australia/australia-reports-record-daily-coronavirus-cases-13-deaths-idUSKCN24V030
[4] https://www.vox.com/2020/7/30/21347047/australia-victoria-melbourne-coronavirus-covid-19
[5] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1059177
[6] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1030592
With all borders closed from Australia, it is taking a big impact.
With all borders closed from Australia, it is taking a big impact.
"Total passengers"?  What if they start carrying partial passengers?
With all borders closed from Australia, it is taking a big impact.

As of June the published covid19 recovery plan has most of the international fleet and a large proportion of domestic fleet grounded for 12months. Employee numbers to be reduced and a significant number or remain on furlough.  16m is 57pc of last years number.  With the recent increase in infection rates any sign of normality for travel seems a long way off.  It’s very very unlikely that 60pc of last years passenger numbers will be reached.

As @Max1673 said domestic flights seem to account for around 64% of all travels and international 36%. International travel should be down to very close to zero and Qantas seem to be on the verge to cancel all international flights bar New Zealand.[1] Domestic passengers was almost 19 millions second half of 2019, but is of course also affected by the pandemic. With the new outbreak in New South Wales the number of flights is drastically reduced to Melbourne.[2]
While we are still early in the second half of the year and a lot can change, all signs point to travel by flight being far below usual numbers.
Readjusting previous prediction:
Less than 16 million: +4
Between 16-20 million: -4 I'm waiting for the report on the first half year of 2020 for Qantas which should be found here when published: https://investor.qantas.com/investors/?page=result-centre The numbers should speak for themselves I think, but there is always a chance I'm surprised. 1. https://www.9news.com.au/national/qantas-cancels-all-international-inventory-precursor-to-flights-until-march-2021/c37b1a4b-88ef-4fd9-ac08-ecc90a34f890
2. https://www.9news.com.au/national/victoria-coronavirus-outbreak-qantas-and-jetstar-reduce-flights-to-and-from-melbourne/ef51fe7f-19a3-4096-b4d0-5dafccc574e5
With all borders closed from Australia, it is taking a big impact.

"Qantas will release 350,000 discounted fares as part of its bid to boost domestic tourism, the major airline announced today." https://au.finance.yahoo.com/news/qantas-cuts-prices-on-350000-seats-013628491.html
With only 6 months to go I am throwing caution to the wind and going whole hog with the first bin.

"there would not be international operations of real scale until July 2021 ... It has begun ramping up domestic flying as state borders reopen and expects to reach 40% of normal capacity in July, an average of around 70% next financial year and 100% in FY22." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-qantas/qantas-cutting-20-of-workforce-and-raising-capital-in-coronavirus-battle-idUSKBN23V3BN

"Qantas will cut at least 6,000 jobs across all parts of the business as part of its long-term response to the coronavirus pandemic and will not resume substantial international travel until July 2021 ... the airline plans to get back to 40 per cent of its pre-crisis domestic flying from July, and 'hopefully more in the months that follow.'" https://www.abc.net.au/news/2020-06-25/qantas-job-cuts-coronavirus-pandemic-covid-19-alan-joyce/12390802

Assuming all flights resume on July 1st, restrictions on passenger numbers through airports and in planes may apply. Add to that many people just will not want to fly, or are successfully working remotely and have no need for business travel.

There are ~26 weeks in the second half of 2020. According to CNN Business, Qantas "is still seeing increasing demand for travel within Australia as local restrictions are slowly lifted. Qantas Group's domestic passenger numbers within the country doubled this week to 64,000 people" [1]. My guess is that this figure is likely to either stay steady or increase given Australia's low case numbers [2] and the fact that most international flights for the rest of the year have been cancelled (so Australians are likely to vacation/travel more within the country via domestic flights) [3]. This implies that there will be at least 1,664,000 passengers (64,000 passengers last week * 26 weeks) — which is still an order of magnitude below 16 million! [1] https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/18/business/australia-qantas-flight-cancellations-intl-hnk/index.html
[2] https://covid19.who.int/region/wpro/country/au
[3] https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-qantas/qantas-to-announce-future-direction-soon-trying-to-avoid-forced-pilot-job-cuts-sources-idUSL4N2DZ19F
With being shut down and the lack of will to want to travel for the foreseeable future I do not see Qantas doing more than 55% of their normal passenger numbers.
They've officially shut down pretty much all international flights except to NZ, and the loss is unlikely to be made up by increased domestic demand.

"Qantas has cancelled all international flights through to October 24 2020, with the exception of services to New Zealand and, at the time of writing, Tokyo/Haneda." [1]  In the second half of 2019, Qantas carried 28,876,000 passengers — 18,895,000 were domestic and 9,981,000 were international [2]. So even if we were to assume that there will be no international travel in the second half of the year (which will not be the case — there will be some!) we could still have ~19 million domestic passengers.  Will this 2019 figure of ~19 million domestic passengers in the second half of 2019 be higher or lower in the second half of 2020? I can see two arguments that push in opposite directions. One is that people seem to be generally less inclined to fly [3], though I can't find any polling of Australians. The other is that Australians may increase their domestic travel so they can vacation in other parts of the country instead of abroad. Pending more information, I'll assume these two effects somewhat cancel out but I will give more weight to a general hesitancy to fly.   [1] https://www.executivetraveller.com/news/qantas-cancels-almost-all-overseas-flights-through-to-late-october
[2] https://investor.qantas.com/FormBuilder/_Resource/_module/doLLG5ufYkCyEPjF1tpgyw/file/2020HY/HY20-Interim-Financial-Report.pdf
[3] https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/meet-the-press/majority-voters-are-uncomfortable-attending-large-gatherings-dining-out-n1226071

HT to @Elizabeth-Wahlenmayer for the background numbers. The year-on-year domestic drop for March was 39% per Australia's stats [1]. Using half the 2018 number from @Elizabeth-Wahlenmayer as a starting point [2], that starts with 27.5 million for half the year. Split that by month gives 4.6 million per month. The numbers for March, assuming grounded international flights and passenger numbers with a 39% drop gives an estimate of 1.1 million carried in March. I'll guess that rises by 10% per month, topping out at 1.84 which is my approximate domestic carrying by Qantas in a normal month. A normal month would have about 2.8 million international travelers. I'll start at 5% of that in July, as everyone is going to be nervous and it will take a while to figure things out as they reopen, then grow by 10% per month after. 	Domestic	International 	Total
July	 1.61         	0.14                	1.75
Aug	 1.77	        0.15	                1.92
Sept 1.84	        0.17	                2.01
Oct	1.84	        0.19	                2.03
Nov	1.84	        0.20                	2.04
Dec	1.84	        0.23                 	2.07
			                          Total: 11.82 I did some experiments with this model and unless the international starts off at 25% percent or higher OR has a higher growth rate than 10%, this sticks well below 16 million. Hedging a bit, as this is a SWAG of a model. [1] https://www.bitre.gov.au/statistics/aviation/domestic
[2] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1023593

Currently, Qantas has halted all international flights at least till the end of July 2020 — https://www.qantas.com/au/en/travel-info/travel-updates/coronavirus/qantas-international-network-changes.html
Local transmission of COVID in Australia is now virtually extinct and nearly all cases are incoming international travellers. This would suggest that the international border is not likely to open anytime soon.
But there is much talk of the economic need for tourism and international students, which would apply pressure to open the border sooner rather than later. 
It seems logical the government will opt for a staged re-opening of the border through the second half of 2020, after July. This leaves a maximum of 5 months, which at H2 2020 rates would equate to 24m passengers.
However, it is also likely that a significant proportion of cancelled H1 trips (business and tourism) may be taken in the second half of the year.
With all these considerations in mind, the likely figure will almost certainly be less than 24m. The question is: by how much? And the will depend most heavily on the government's schedule for re-opening the border.
Given that the biggest factor influencing that decision is the progress of COVID worldwide, and that that doesn't look like slowing down anytime soon, I have wagered that the border will be opened slowly and selectively, which favours the lower figure. UPDATE 25 June: https://www.sbs.com.au/news/how-long-will-australians-have-to-wait-to-travel-overseas-again —international travel looks like being largely off limits for the rest of the year. Also, QANTAS announced today they're laying off 6000 employees and grounding 100 planes for 12 months: https://www.sbs.com.au/news/qantas-to-cut-6-000-jobs-slash-costs-as-part-of-coronavirus-recovery-plan
Too many uncertainties to make a good prediction.
No chance air travel will recover this year and long haul which would be a large part of Oz travel least likely of all.
Air travel will be negatively impacted long term

https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-8386343/Qantas-Jetstar-add-300-domestic-return-flights-week-travel-restrictions-ease.html
Still would not be enough to go over 16 million.
australia Covid cases are low. Domestic travel restrictions are easing. talks of opening up tourism with other low risk neighbouring countries.
Shaving a bit, I just cannot imagine travel at the levels that used to be common. Not until there is some change in infections.
Tourism will be limited during Q2, assume more flights in second half of the year, but no where near previous levels. Current travel bubble is limited to NZ, who don't get out that oftern.
Covid-19 will most likely be with us in the autumn hampering air travel severely. Even if it isn't I predict air travel will be down since personal economic uncertainty for many will be high.

"The impact on air travel from the coronavirus will be felt for many years to come, according to the International Air Transport Association, which estimates that passenger traffic won’t rebound to pre-crisis levels until at least 2023." https://www.cnbc.com/2020/05/14/coronavirus-air-travel-wont-return-to-pre-crisis-levels-until-2023-iata-chief-warns.html
covid 19 will massively restirct all international travel this year
Maybe Aussies will feel lucky enough to start flying again. I don't feel that lucky.

Australia doesn't appear to publish numbers per day like the TSA, and their last available data is from Feb [1], so it is difficult to understand how much the traffic has dropped. The TSA's numbers are at about 5% currently. Qantas domestic travel is at 40% of flights running, with international flights grounded through the end of May [3], though that doesn't give much insight into how full the flights running are. Since passengers are going to be slow to return, there will certainly be a dip. I am putting it on the low-end for now. [1] https://www.bitre.gov.au/statistics/aviation/domestic
[2] https://www.tsa.gov/coronavirus/passenger-throughput
[3] https://thepointsguy.com/news/qantas-to-end-international-flying-through-may-ground-all-wide-bodies/

Quanta's carries around 55 million passengers per year. Maybe this could be split as 25 million in the first half and 30 million in the second half.  Assuming that travel will fall by 50% (at least) - we should end up with a 98% chance of less than 16 million people.

Expect slow reintroduction of international flights. Aus-NZ flights may reopen earlier than to other destinations, but I expect this would not result in large passenger numbers, and would be split with AirNZ. 
Expect domestic flights to increase from current numbers but still remain down from previous levels due to suppressed business activity and spending, higher unemployment resulting in fewer holiday travellers. 
On the other hand, Qantas' main domestic rival, Virgin, is in administration and so expect Qantas to pick up a larger slice of the domestic market.

UPDATED: 
In a typical year, more than 28 million passengers would likely be carried. Qantas Airways Limited has demonstrated growth in passengers carried, seats available, and revenue from 2014 to 2019. This includes carrying 48,776,000 passengers in 2014; 52,681,000 in 2016; and 55,273,000 in 2018 according to tables in the 2018 Annual Report.
However, the COVID-19 pandemic has halted significant portions of air travel. Two trends used to forecast the impact this will have on the total passengers carried in the second half of the year include Australia's recovery from COVID-19 and Qantas' domestic flights. 
Approximately four months passed in China from the first cases until a day without new cases and it continues to see less than 100 to 200 new cases per day. Like other countries, China has restricted international travel. As a result it is likely that Australia will see major recovery by July, although international travel limits may remain in place.  
Qantas has suspended nearly all international flights and cut domestic capacity by 60% to deal with the current drop in demand for flights. On the other hand, Qantas is financially stable, has a broad domestic network, and expects to see pent up demand after COVID-19. Domestic flights alone may bring Qantas 12 to 13 million passengers at 80% of domestic capacity because Qantas carried over 32 million passengers on domestic flights in 2019.  Domestic travel may sustain passenger numbers from prior years if a COVID-19 recovery is seen early in June and July. Total passengers carried in the second half of the year is most likely to fall under 20 million, because international travel will remain limited and makes up approximately a third of Qantas' flights.   https://investor.qantas.com/FormBuilder/_Resource/_module/doLLG5ufYkCyEPjF1tpgyw/file/data-book/2019qantasdatabook.pdf
https://centreforaviation.com/analysis/reports/qantas-cuts-deep-but-well-placed-to-weather-covid-19-518552

Australia inbound tourists less likely to be impacted on numbers than other markets, as it's a long haul destination where 2 week isolation in good weather and low population density might seem more rational than other locations, if the govt allows it! Even still, almost certainly at least half the usual passengers for the rest of the year.

It carried ~55M last year. Australia is likely to have eradicated corona in the coming months, so there is no way it will let international travelers arrive carrying corona. Domestic travel, including to New Zealand, will surge, and Aussies will holiday in Australia. And they live travelling. The question is, will the likes of SIngapore airlines be allowed to operate domestically, if Virgin fails and take half the seats. Likely. And so numbers could be back to normal, meaning somewhere between 10m and 30m passengers.
Notable effect on airline traffic for next 12 months expected, July/August month with lower than usual traffic.
Just moving towards the crowd forecast

I just cannot imagine getting on a plane in LA and sitting for a day to get off in Sydney in the current climate.
I don't have the spare cash for a month in the outback and no one can convince me we'll be medically able to do so in 6 months time. In a year perhaps once this is sorted, but anyting in 2020 seems risky.

The more I consider this, the more dire my prediction. If there is a definitive avoidance procedure known and practiced, or a cure or vaccine, life can resume,  however, the wealth that has evaporated to date will throttle travel for some time.
Will tourism return to Australia in 2H2020. How many will want to get on a plane? How many will have money for an exotic expensive trip. The economy may rebound, but will travel?
Travel restrictions will likely be lifted, but decreased confidence is sure to remain and financial recession will persist.
This is my first forecast I've submitted on this platform. This is me just trying to see how it works.

I think question is mostly about when and how the demand for the airline is going to recover from covid-19. Qantas displayed 2 solid years, without much change, and there is not much reason for crazy change in the supply of Qantas. The government provided a solid package of about $A 1 billion to airlines, which focused on the big airlines such as Qantas and therefore I feel that despite the cuts and change to operations they had to make, the airline will not be significantly weakened in the short run.
Now for the demand side. Most articles I have read have given a timeline of roughly 4-7 months for demand to increase again. This is much more global and severe than SARS which took a bit less time than this for demand of tourism to recover in Asia. An important factor is that Qantas is focused on international air, which means that it will be badly hit in demand. However, its data books show that roughly 40% of its flights are to and from Asia, which has recovered much more quickly and effectively from the virus. This suggests that this portion of passengers will not change much. However for its flights elsewhere, it will take a siginficant amount of time for demand to recover.

When will the pandemic peak?  That is both unknown and unpredictable, so I had to split my percentages over
the most likely instances.

Evaluating the base rate (excl. COVID-19) - the H2 carried pasengers for the last 3y (in thousands):
2017	28,138
2018	28,500
2019	28,876
-> growth of 1.3% pa, ie 2020: 29.3mn passengers According to the annual report, 64% of the flights are domestic, 36% international. It is likely that the domestic flights will fly earlier and more regularly than the international ones (to avoid spreading possible infections, see China where new infections are mostly driven by citizens returning home). The international flights will likely not pick up significantly until the situation is resolved around the globe. Covid situation:
- China seems to have virus under control for now (but still getting new cases, mostly "imported" via citizens returning from abroad)
- Europe in lock-down at least until Easter, not unlikely even longer
- US, starting to lock-down now (50% currently)
- exit from lock-down will be slow to avoid new spike in infections; international travel will likely be one of the last things to return to pre-Corona levels
- currently unliked that will be back to normal around the globe on 01 July
- as long as infections are not under control, likely to be behavioral impact, ie many people will want to avoid flights
- given time period is forward starting in 3 months for 6 months uncertainty in judging probabilities is currently very high Scenarios:
- Assuming 90% of domestic flights and 70% of international flights fly during H2 then we get to around 24mn passengers for H2 in total. 
- 60% domestic / 50% international lead to around 16mn

Yearly passengers for Qantas are around 55-60 million about half of them are on domestic flights. 
Willingness of people to travel will remain low in second half of 2020.
Keeping 50% of domestic passengers and 25% of international travelers would result on around 20 million passenger.

This is tough, China's airlines seem to have recovered somewhat from their lows already. But the rest of the world isn't containing the virus as well as China claims to have done. On the other hand, Quantas may not exist in a few months. There will probably be massive layoffs, and they may not even be able to fly that many passengers by Q3/4 2020. The signs are pointing pretty strongly towards the bottom bucket. https://www.economist.com/business/2020/03/15/coronavirus-is-grounding-the-worlds-airlines
https://skift.com/2018/09/14/10-years-later-how-the-travel-industry-came-back-from-the-financial-crisis/

Hattip @fisherdbus for insights into how this might unfold. Assume Q3 at half normal rate and Q4 at normal rate.
7+14=21 as an upper bound. Destinations may have not all recovered by Q3. Tourism will likely still be weak in 2020. How many will be eager to board a plane for a full day in a confined space?

Qantas Airways Limited has demonstrated growth in passengers carried, seats available, and revenue from 2014 to 2019. This includes carrying 48,776,000 passengers in 2014; 52,681,000 in 2016; and 55,273,000 in 2018 according to tables in the 2018 Annual Report.  In consideration of the impact of coronavirus, I examined the John Hopkins map tracking confirmed cases as well as news articles. Approximately four months passed in China from the first cases until a day without new cases. Like other countries, China has also closed its borders to the majority of foreigners.  From these two trends, I believe that Australia's recovery will begin by July, though international air travel may remain limited. If full recovery was achieved, more than 28 million passengers would likely be carried based on Qantas' growth. However, due to border restrictions, a moderate recovery is more likely.  https://investor.qantas.com/FormBuilder/_Resource/_module/doLLG5ufYkCyEPjF1tpgyw/file/annual-reports/2018-Annual-Report-ASX.pdf
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/china/
